data: FOMENTO DE LAS COMPETENCIAS DIGITALES EN LOS JÓVENES

DIGICOMING project (Promoting Digital Skills among Young People) has as its main objective to identify the key digital competences necessary to improve employability, promoting them from an inclusive point of view in an international context. Thanks to the project, the participants will have the opportunity to:

-	Get closer to the technological world from different perspectives: the emerging digital industries, search for jobs using Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs), lifelong learning and certification and digital citizenship. 
-	Raise their awareness about the importance of ICTs to improve people’s quality of life and accessibility in cities.
-	Reduce the digital gap between different groups to improve their employability.
-	Get to know the resources their city has to improve their employability.
-	Develop communication, team working and organizational skills, since the young participants are responsible for designing the activities before carrying them out. These skills are highly valued when it comes to improving their employability.
-	Promote multilingualism and cultural exchanges, advocating for multiculturalism and the wealth present in different cultures. In this way, values like solidarity and cooperation are reinforced.

The project has been designed around a bilateral exchange lasting two weeks, one taking place in Gijón, Spain and the other in Hartlepool, United Kingdom. At least 16 youths from both countries will be able to participate.

The youths, with ages ranging from 18 to 30 years old and from both countries, will currently be unemployed, but they will have complementary profiles to promote synergies and social inclusion.

The theme will be “Smart Gijón” for Gijón’s mobility. The young participants will be able learn and experiment with different initiatives related with future smart cities where an ecosystem of companies, organizations, education centres and associations use new technologies to improve the citizens’ quality of life. They will also have the opportunity to learn about what is behind the new technologies and develop a group challenge about how youths view the cities of the future.

Regarding Hartlepool’s mobility, it will be called “i-Hartlepool” and based on digital inclusion, since the city is already carrying out an ambitious Digital Inclusion Plan. Different activities to promote audiovisual/digital competences will be organized as means of developing in a group a digital marketing strategy to position Hartlepool as a tourist destination as well as a project about an Erasmus student’s life using digital resources.

The young participants will be in charge of organizing the mobilities and the activities related to the communication, evaluation and monitoring of the project throughout its duration with support from both organizations.

As the project advances, the youths will be able to acquire and update their competences in new technologies. Moreover, they will gain experience managing and developing projects. Furthermore they will have the chance to learn about other countries, their labour markets and the opportunities they can offer.

Thanks to the DIGICOMING projects the young participants will be able to identify the key digital competences to improve their employability while at the same time raising their awareness about the importance of new technologies in the future while working on digital inclusion and responsible use aspects.

In addition, the project is a great opportunity to highlight the talent and initiative of the youths that are part of the European Union (EU) thanks to the organization of the project’s exchanges, as well as to identify their needs and offer them a space to express their opinions, ideas and future perspectives.

Ultimately, the young participants will be to join a strong digital economy necessary for the innovation, growth, sustainable growth and employment and competitiveness of the European Union Member States. DIGICOMING Project will contribute to it as well as the achievement of the Europe 2020 Strategy by forming the basis of practical and useful knowledge and competences in the youths that will become the future of the European Union.

The Erasmus + Program will contribute to the Europe 2020 Strategy with the aim of seeking smart, inclusive and sustainable growth;quality education and training, successful labour market integration and more mobility of young people which will release all youngpeople’s potential and support the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives.Both of our areas and countries are facing the major problem of youth unemployment and to conquer this issue we need to findsolutions for young people with a key outcome being working abroad. However, there are still many obstacles that hinder freemovement and these issues need to be overcome to make it easier for young people to move and work within the European Unionaswell as acquire new skills and competences. Young people are often willing to work abroad, but do not take up job opportunitiesin other countries because they are not aware of them, high costs of moving or language barriers.The participants will be aged between 16 and 30 years old and will come from three main groups: -1. Young people that need support to find a job or a training course abroad;2. Young people with less possibility of gaining employment abroad in order to open their minds to the potential opportunity, and;3. Young people who are disadvantaged with the aim of giving them an unique opportunity and to increase their self-confidence.The young people who will participate in the project will acquire a range of skills and knowledge which will improve theiremployment opportunities and allow them to succeed in life. The young people from each institution will responsible of the whole organisation of the mobility in their country.The project objective is to 'activate' young people and raise awareness of the employment opportunities available abroad indifferent European countries. The activities during the mobility’s will be organised by the participants however they will be aroundfive key areas which are interculturality, entrepreneurship, employment, volunteering and education. The project will be organisedaround two mobility’s taking place in April and May 2016 with at least 16 young people participating in each mobility (8from each country). The plan is for one exchange to take place in Hartlepool and the other in Gijón. The direct beneficiaries of themobilities will be 16 people (young people that are going to travel) accompanied by their tutors and we will try to involve more young people during the local activities of the exchanges.

This project will deliver personalised education, employment and enterprise pathways for young people aged 15 to 29. It will ensure existing best practice, such as Talent Match, is rolled out across the Tees Valley through the development and delivery of alternative education, work-related learning, sector routeways, virtual learning and enterprise programmes. Quality work experience will be secured for all participants through volunteering, traineeships, internships, work trials and work placements with employers. Ring-fenced flexible funds will offer additional learning and skills removing final barriers to ensure progression into education, employment and training.

This project will provide tailored routeways for young people aged 15 to 29 years old to enter into priority employment sectors which are detailed within the Tees Valley Strategic Economic Plan including Digital and Logistics. The routeways will include employability and enterprise training, wrap-around support, work experience and one-to-one careers advice and guidance which will ensure hard to reach young people move closer to the labour market. Key to the success of the project will be employer engagement with companies across the sub-region to ensure that participants completing the routeways will progress into priority sector employment placements already secured
